articles.headline: For Migrant Children in Federal Care, a ‘Sense of Desperation’
articles.snippet: Interviews and a Times review showed a shelter system with wildly varying conditions, some of which are far below the standard that the Biden administration has promised.
articles.abstract: Interviews and a Times review showed a shelter system with wildly varying conditions, some of which are far below the standard that the Biden administration has promised.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a federal shelter in Dallas, migrant children sleep in a windowless convention center room under fluorescent lights that never go dark.

articles.headline: CNN’s Zucker, Reunited With a Powerful Friend, Sees His Fortunes Change
articles.snippet: Phone buddies and golf partners, Jeff Zucker and David Zaslav have a 30-year history. Now Zucker may be open to working for the man he calls a “best friend.”
articles.abstract: Phone buddies and golf partners, Jeff Zucker and David Zaslav have a 30-year history. Now Zucker may be open to working for the man he calls a “best friend.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, the future looked hazy for Jeff Zucker, the pugnacious president of CNN.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin

articles.headline: After Media Detour, AT&T Confronts Old Problems
articles.snippet: Following its spinoff of WarnerMedia, AT&T is back to primarily being a wireless company, with all of the challenges that entails.
articles.abstract: Following its spinoff of WarnerMedia, AT&T is back to primarily being a wireless company, with all of the challenges that entails.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a meeting of AT&T’s top leaders at the company’s headquarters in Dallas, Randall L. Stephenson, the chief executive, sounded a victory note. The wireless provider was on the verge of a transformative deal that would turn the phone company into a tech and media giant.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Gaza War Deepens a Long-Running Humanitarian Crisis
articles.snippet: The Palestinian enclave was already in a dire state. The war with Israel has made it worse, damaging the health and sewage systems, closing schools and displacing tens of thousands.
articles.abstract: The Palestinian enclave was already in a dire state. The war with Israel has made it worse, damaging the health and sewage systems, closing schools and displacing tens of thousands.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — The nine-day battle between Hamas militants and the Israeli military has damaged 17 hospitals and clinics in Gaza, wrecked its only coronavirus test laboratory, sent fetid wastewater into its streets and broke water pipes serving at least 800,000 people, setting off a humanitarian crisis that is touching nearly every civilian in the crowded enclave of about two million people.
articles.byline: By Iyad Abuheweila, Adam Rasgon, Isabel Kershner and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Publicly Supportive, Biden Is Said to Sharpen His Tone With Netanyahu in Private
articles.snippet: Mr. Biden has spoken publicly about how he once sent Mr. Netanyahu a photograph with the inscription, “Bibi, I don’t agree with a damn thing you say, but I love you.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Biden has spoken publicly about how he once sent Mr. Netanyahu a photograph with the inscription, “Bibi, I don’t agree with a damn thing you say, but I love you.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden has maintained his public support toward Israel even as he adopted a somewhat sharper private tone with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, a calculus shaped by Mr. Biden’s longtime relationship with the Israeli leader as well as by growing hopes that Israel’s military operations against Hamas are nearing an end.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Going Green, or Greenwashing? A Proposed Climate Law Divides France.
articles.snippet: Emmanuel Macron’s credentials as a leader on climate issues are being tested as business and environmental groups spar over changes to the French way of life.
articles.abstract: Emmanuel Macron’s credentials as a leader on climate issues are being tested as business and environmental groups spar over changes to the French way of life.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Less meat in French cafeterias. Bans on short-distance flights.  Gas heaters on cafe terraces would be outlawed.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: Banks Fight $4 Billion Debt Relief Plan for Black Farmers
articles.snippet: Lenders are pressuring the Agriculture Department to give them more money, saying quick repayments will cut into profits.
articles.abstract: Lenders are pressuring the Agriculture Department to give them more money, saying quick repayments will cut into profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration’s efforts to provide $4 billion in debt relief to minority farmers is encountering stiff resistance from banks, which are complaining that the government initiative to pay off the loans of borrowers who have faced decades of financial discrimination will cut into their profits and hurt investors.

articles.headline: An ‘Army of 16-Year-Olds’ Takes On the Democrats
articles.snippet: Young progressives are an unpredictable new factor in Massachusetts elections. They’re ardent, and organized, and they don’t take orders.
articles.abstract: Young progressives are an unpredictable new factor in Massachusetts elections. They’re ardent, and organized, and they don’t take orders.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Dana Depelteau, a hotel manager, had just gone public with a long-shot candidacy for mayor in Boston when he noticed that someone in city politics was going after him online.
